Expectation1: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation1: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I glanced at the clock on the workshop wall, feeling the weight of the afternoon pressing down on me. The operator, Mark, was at it again—fiddling with the machine’s settings, ignoring the guidelines I’d explained just yesterday. The whir of the conveyor was punctuated by the clatter of wasted material, piling up faster than I could count. My job demanded I step in, guide him firmly, maybe even report the repeated mistakes. But as I opened my mouth, my phone buzzed with a reminder: church service in thirty minutes. I’d promised myself, and my congregation, that I’d be there—worshipping, connecting, being present in faith and fellowship. The expectation was clear: my presence mattered, not just to me, but to the community that counted on me. Yet here I was, torn between my duty to guide Mark and prevent further waste, and my commitment to my faith. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment I’d cause on either side, feeling the tension coil tighter with every wasted sheet and every passing minute.
